name: Frauds and Mistakes in History Quiz | History | 10 Questions

questions.text: Howard Hughes made news shortly before his death when an autobiography of him proved to be bogus. Who perpetrated the hoax?
questions.explanation:
Clifford Irving.

	Nice try - but it didn't fly.

questions.text: A so-called discovery of a new species of prehistoric man ultimately proved to be false. This 'discovery' was known as:
questions.explanation:
Piltdown Man.

	It looked good at first ... but faded.

questions.text: A writer has made claims that ancient peoples were visited by beings from outer space. His books, such as 'Chariots of the Gods?' and others, have been rejected by the scientific community. Who is he?
questions.explanation:
Erich Van Daniken.

	Interesting ideas - but the scientific community generally finds his explanations and 'proofs' to be lacking.

questions.text: 'Diaries' of this man that were 'discovered' in the latter part of the 20th century proved to be false:
questions.explanation:
Hitler.

	'The Hitler Diaries', as they were called. Too bad they weren't real.

questions.text: Mata Hari's name today is synonymous with espionage. In what war did she perform her spying?
questions.explanation:
World War I.

	Everyone knows her name - and not much else about her.

questions.text: This explorer searched for - but never found -'The Seven Cities of Gold' (Seven Cities of Cibola).
questions.explanation:
Coronado.

	Imagine: streets paved with gold!

questions.text: This explorer unsuccessfully tried to find the 'Fountain of Youth':
questions.explanation:
Ponce De Leon.

	Great idea - but, not to be.

questions.text: The practice of voodoo is most closely associated with:
Dreams, once thought to be meaningless, were described by this scientific pioneer as being 'the royal road to the unconscious':
questions.explanation:
Freud.

	One of Freud's most famous quotes.

questions.text: The attempt to change lead (or other comparable material) into gold was known as:
questions.explanation:
Alchemy.

	Another fine idea that didn't quite pan out.
